questions.answerB: Stays in one portion of a lane at all times.
questions.answerC: Weaves within the lane to be more visible.
questions.answerD: Travels only on the oily portion of the lane.
questions.explanation: Unlike drivers of larger vehicles, a motorcyclist has three lane position options in their travel lane. The rider should select whichever position is safest based on road and traffic conditions.

questions.question: If hazards are on your left, you should ride:
questions.answerA: In the left portion of the lane.
questions.answerB: In the right portion of the lane.
questions.answerC: In any portion of the lane.
questions.answerD: On the shoulder.
questions.explanation: When hazards exist to your left, it is often best to ride in the right portion of the lane. Be prepared to adjust your lane position as road and traffic conditions change.

questions.question: Which fabric provides the best protection for motorcycle riders?
questions.answerD: Polyester
questions.explanation: Jackets and pants made of leather offer the greatest degree of protection to those riding motorcycles.

questions.question: When riding a motorcycle and trying to turn, you should:
questions.answerA: Press the grip in the direction you want to turn.
questions.answerB: Press the grip opposite of the direction you want to turn.
questions.answerC: Not hold the grip because it can be dangerous.
questions.answerD: Not lean the motorcycle as that can be unsafe.
questions.explanation: When traveling faster than a walking pace, your motorcycle will need to lean to turn. Pressing the grip in the direction you want to turn will cause you to lean in the appropriate direction

questions.question: It is important to flash your brake light when:
questions.answerB: You will be slowing where other drivers won't expect it.
questions.answerC: There is a stop sign ahead.
questions.answerD: Your signals are not working.
questions.explanation: Motorcycle brake lights are more difficult to see than the brake lights of larger vehicles, so flashing your brake light may help other drivers to notice it. You should flash you brake light before slowing down where other drivers may not expect you to slow down, such as in the middle of a block or when approaching an alley.

questions.question: Which fabric provides the most protection when worn by motorcyclists?
questions.answerD: Wool
questions.explanation: Leather jackets and pants provide the greatest level of protection when riding.

questions.question: A potential danger of braking too hard is:
questions.answerA: Losing traction on one or both wheels.
questions.answerB: Coming to a complete stop before you expect to.
questions.answerD: Taking too long to stop.
questions.explanation: If you over-apply your brakes, you may lose traction on one or both wheels and crash.

questions.question: When braking on a slippery surface, you should:
questions.answerD: Not use any brakes, but downshift.
questions.explanation: To ride safely on a slippery surface, you should reduce your speed and avoid making sudden moves. Use both brakes if you must slow down or stop.

questions.question: When riding in a group, inexperienced riders should position themselves:
questions.answerC: At the tail end of the group.
questions.answerD: Beside the leader.
questions.explanation: In a group of motorcyclists, riders with less experience should be positioned toward the front of the group, just behind the leader. This will allow more experienced riders to keep an eye on them without forcing the inexperienced rider to lead the group.

questions.question: Your motorcycle’s brake light is:
questions.answerA: More noticeable than a car’s brake lights.
questions.answerB: Less noticeable than a car’s brake lights.
questions.answerC: Less important than a car’s brake lights.
questions.answerD: More easily seen than a car’s brake lights.
questions.explanation: The brake light of a motorcycle is usually not as noticeable as the brake lights of a car. Flashing your brake light before slowing or stopping can help other drivers notice that you are about to brake.

questions.question: To help provide space for drivers attempting to merge into your lane from an entrance ramp, you should:
questions.answerB: Merge into the next lane, if possible.
questions.answerC: Not worry about it, since they are the ones trying to merge.
questions.answerD: Ride on the far left shoulder.
questions.explanation: Drivers merging onto a highway and into your lane may not notice your motorcycle. Give them plenty of space to safely merge by moving into a different lane, if you can.

questions.question: The front brake supplies how much of a motorcycle's stopping power?
questions.answerD: All the stopping power
questions.explanation: The front brake of a motorcycle is more powerful than the rear brake. It can provide three-fourths of the bike's total stopping power.

questions.question: If your motorcycle begins to wobble, you should:
questions.answerA: Keep riding, as the wobble will likely correct itself.
questions.answerC: Close the throttle to slow down.
questions.answerD: Accelerate quickly.
questions.explanation: Trying to accelerate out of a wobble will only increase the problem. Instead, grip the handlebars firmly, slow down while gradually closing the throttle, move your weight as far forward and downward as you can, and pull off the road as soon as you can. Once off the road, you should address the problem causing the wobble.

questions.question: Unlike most food and drinks, alcohol does not need to be digested. This means that:
questions.answerA: Within minutes of being consumed, the alcohol reaches the brain and begins to affect the drinker.
questions.answerB: The alcohol never gets removed from the body.
questions.answerC: It takes a long time to feel the effects of alcohol.
questions.answerD: Once it is in your system, your body gets rid of the alcohol quickly.
questions.explanation: Because it does not have to be digested, alcohol enters a person's bloodstream quickly and reaches the brain within minutes. It gets eliminated from the body at a relatively slow rate: about one drink per hour.

questions.question: Riding gloves are often:
questions.answerD: Unsafe for the rider.
questions.explanation: Gloves designed for motorcycle riding are usually made of leather. In addition to improving your grip, gloves provide protection for a rider's hands and fingers.

questions.question: When riding with a passenger, you should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Ride more slowly than you would normally.
questions.answerB: Start slowing earlier than you would normally.
questions.answerD: Not communicate with the passenger while riding.
questions.explanation: Because of a passenger's additional weight, a motorcycle will respond more slowly with a passenger on board than with just one occupant. With a passenger, you should travel a bit more slowly than you normally would, start slowing sooner than you normally would, and increase your following distance. Always warn your passenger of any special conditions ahead.

questions.question: Several factors influence blood alcohol concentration (BAC). Which of the following does not play a role?
questions.answerD: Height
questions.explanation: There are several major factors that can affect a person's blood alcohol concentration (BAC). A BAC is determined in part by the amount of alcohol someone has consumed, how fast they consumed the alcohol, and their body weight.

questions.question: Small vehicles can appear ______ and seem to be traveling ______ than they actually are.
questions.answerD: Closer, faster
questions.explanation: Small vehicles, like motorcycles, can visually seem to be farther away and moving more slowly than they actually are. This phenomenon can make it difficult for others on the road to accurately judge the location and speed of a smaller vehicle.

questions.question: Linked and integrated braking systems:
questions.answerB: Connect the front and rear brakes.
questions.answerD: Should be avoided because they reduce a rider's control.
questions.explanation: Linked braking systems apply both brakes when the rider applies either one. An integrated braking system is a variant of this in which partial front braking is applied any time the rear brake is activated. These braking systems ensure that both brakes are used each time the rider slows or stops.

questions.question: When you are being passed from behind, you should:
questions.answerA: Ride in the center portion of the lane.
questions.answerB: Ride in the left portion of the lane.
questions.answerC: Ride in the right portion of the lane.
questions.answerD: Ride in any portion of the lane.
questions.explanation: When you are being passed from behind, stay in the center portion of your lane. This will discourage the other driver from re-entering your lane before it is safe.

questions.question: When riding at night, how should your following distance compare to your following distance during the day?
questions.answerA: You should allow a longer following distance when following another vehicle at night.
questions.answerB: You should allow a shorter following distance when following another vehicle at night.
questions.answerC: You should always maintain the same following distance regardless of the time of day.
questions.answerD: Following distance really doesn’t matter.
questions.explanation: Distances are difficult to judge in the dark because visual cues (like shadows and light contrasts) can be missing or distorted. You should allow a longer following distance when riding at night than you do when riding during the day.

questions.question: A plastic, shatter-resistant face shield:
questions.answerA: Is not necessary if you have a windshield.
questions.answerD: Does not protect your face as effectively as goggles.
questions.explanation: A plastic, shatter-resistant face shield protects your entire face in a crash. Goggles protect your eyes, but not the rest of your face. A windshield is not an adequate substitute for a face shield or goggles.

questions.question: What can help reduce the risk of a head or neck injury in the event of a crash?
questions.answerD: Not allowing a passenger on the motorcycle
questions.explanation: Wearing a helmet is the single most effective thing you can do to reduce the risk of head or neck injuries in the event of a crash.

questions.question: When passing another vehicle:
questions.answerA: The pass may be completed in a no passing zone.
questions.answerB: The rider may travel up to 10 mph over the speed limit to complete the pass.
questions.answerC: The pass must be started and completed within a passing zone.
questions.answerD: The pass must be completed on the shoulder, if one is present.
questions.explanation: Passing must be completed within the posted speed limits, and only in areas where passing is safe and legal.

questions.question: If braking in a curve:
questions.answerB: It will be the same as braking on a straightaway.
questions.answerC: You will have more traction as you lean into the curve.
questions.answerD: You may have less traction as you lean into the curve.
questions.explanation: It is possible to use both brakes while turning, but it must be done with great care. Some of the tires' usual traction is being used to make the turn while the motorcycle is leaning, so less traction is available for stopping.

questions.question: Gloves can:
questions.answerA: Make it difficult to control a motorcycle and should be avoided.
questions.answerC: Provide an improved grip on the handlebars.
questions.answerD: Offer no protection.
questions.explanation: Gloves can provide you with an improved grip on your motorcycle's handlebars. They can also protect your hands in the event of a crash.

questions.question: When a vehicle attempts to pass you from behind, you should:
questions.answerA: Move to the center portion of the lane.
questions.answerB: Move to the left portion of the lane.
questions.answerC: Move to the right portion of the lane.
questions.answerD: Not be concerned about which portion of the lane you are using.
questions.explanation: When being passed, it is generally best to ride in the center portion of your lane. Being too close to the passing vehicle increases the risk of a collision.

questions.question: You should increase your following distance if:
questions.answerC: You can see through the vehicle ahead of you.
questions.answerD: The sun is out.
questions.explanation: An expanded cushion of space is needed if your motorcycle will take longer than normal to stop. If the pavement is slippery, if you cannot see through the vehicle ahead of you, or if traffic is heavy and another driver may try to squeeze in front of you, open up to a larger following distance.

questions.question: Maximum front-line braking is accomplished by:
questions.answerD: Using the rear brake while downshifting.
questions.explanation: Maximum straight-line braking is accomplished by fully applying both the front and rear brakes without locking either wheel. You should always use both brakes every time you slow or stop.

questions.question: If your motorcycle starts to wobble, it is best to:
questions.answerC: Grip the handlebars firmly and close the throttle gradually.
questions.answerD: Gradually apply your brakes.
questions.explanation: Do not try to accelerate out of a wobble because doing so will only make the motorcycle more unstable. Instead, grip the handlebars firmly, slow down by gradually closing the throttle, move your weight as far forward and downward as possible, and pull off the road as soon as you can. Avoid applying the brakes, as this may also worsen the wobble.

questions.question: To stop quickly, you should:
questions.answerA: Rely only on the front brake.
questions.answerB: Rely only on the rear brake.
questions.answerC: Use the front brake and then the rear brake.
questions.answerD: Use both brakes at the same time.
questions.explanation: If you need to stop quickly, you should apply both brakes at the same time.

questions.question: It is difficult for other motorists to see motorcycles at night. To make up for that, a motorcycle rider should:
questions.answerA: Reduce their speed when riding at night.
questions.answerB: Sound their horn repeatedly when riding at night.
questions.answerD: Stay directly in front of another vehicle to be seen in their headlights when riding at night.
questions.explanation: Strategies for safely riding at night include reducing your speed, increasing your following distance, using the lights of the car ahead to help see farther down the road, using your high beam headlight (unless following or meeting another vehicle), and being flexible about your lane position.

questions.question: When changing lanes, you should:
questions.answerA: Signal, use your mirrors, and turn your head.
questions.answerC: Turn your head and change lanes.
questions.answerD: Signal and change lanes.
questions.explanation: Always use the proper turn signal before a turn or lane change. Use your mirrors and perform head checks before changing lanes to check for traffic surrounding your vehicle.

questions.question: If you must stop quickly in a curve, you should:
questions.answerA: Straighten up, square the handlebars, and stop.
questions.answerB: Abruptly apply both brakes while leaning.
questions.answerD: Apply only the front brake.
questions.explanation: If you must stop quickly while in a curve, you should first straighten and square the handlebars, then stop. If straightening your motorcycle is not possible, you should apply the brakes smoothly and gradually, reduce your lean angle, then increase the brake pressure as you slow down.

questions.question: When both braking and swerving must be done to avoid an unexpected hazard, a rider should:
questions.answerA: Perform one action, then the other.
questions.answerB: Perform both actions at the same time and apply extra braking pressure.
questions.answerC: Perform both actions at the same time, but mainly focus on swerving.
questions.answerD: Not perform either action.
questions.explanation: Because you need adequate traction to swerve safely, you should not brake and swerve at the same time. Instead, if you approach a hazard that requires you to brake and swerve, you should perform one action and then the other.

questions.question: A plastic, shatter-resistant face shield:
questions.answerA: Is not necessary if you have a windshield.
questions.answerD: Does not protect your face as well as goggles.
questions.explanation: A plastic, shatter-resistant face shield can help protect your whole face in a crash. While goggles can protect your eyes, they won't protect the rest of your face. A windshield is not a substitute for a face shield or goggles.

questions.question: Riding alongside another rider:
questions.answerA: Allows you to maximize the surface of the road.
questions.answerB: Should be avoided because it limits your escape routes.
questions.answerC: Allows you to communicate with one another.
questions.answerD: Makes it easier for other motorists to pass.
questions.explanation: You should not ride alongside another motorcyclist because doing so will limit both of your possible routes of escape if you encounter a hazard.

questions.question: In general, the body gets rid of almost ______ per hour.
questions.answerD: Four drinks
questions.explanation: On average, a person's body can eliminate the alcohol content of about one drink per hour.

questions.question: When changing lanes:
questions.answerA: There is no need to do a head check if you use your mirrors.
questions.answerB: Mirrors provide a full view of the road around your motorcycle.
questions.answerC: You should turn your head and look over your shoulder.
questions.answerD: You can assume drivers will properly respond to your turn signal.
questions.explanation: Motorcycles have blind spots just like any other vehicle. Always turn your head and look over your shoulder to check for traffic in your blind spot before changing lanes.

questions.question: To receive maximum protection, wear a helmet that is certified by the:
questions.answerD: National Association of Helmets.
questions.explanation: To get maximum protection, use a motorcycle helmet that meets U.S. Department of Transportation (DOT) standards.

questions.question: A helmet will not provide the best possible protection:
questions.answerA: If it is certified by the DOT.
questions.answerC: If it is free of defects.
questions.answerD: If it has cracks.
questions.explanation: A helmet should meet U.S. Department of Transportation (DOT) and state standards and fit snugly all the way around to provide maximum protection. It should be free of defects such as cracks, loose padding, or frayed straps.

questions.question: If your motorcycle begins to weave while you are riding over rain grooves or bridge gratings, you should:
questions.answerA: Relax, maintain a steady speed, and ride straight across the surface.
questions.answerB: Tighten your hold on the handle grips and increase your speed to get past the hazard.
questions.answerD: Ride on the shoulder instead of on the grooves.
questions.explanation: The weaving motion that occurs when a motorcycle rides over rain grooves or bridge gratings is generally not dangerous. If you experience weaving when riding over one of these surfaces, simply relax and proceed straight across the grooves or gratings at a steady speed. Trying to compensate for the weaving motion by zigzagging is more dangerous than riding straight.

questions.question: To lessen your chances of being involved in a crash, you should:
questions.answerA: Use your turn signals to indicate that you plan to change lanes.
questions.answerC: Keep your eyes focused no more than 15 feet in front of your motorcycle.
questions.answerD: Not use a headlight during the day.
questions.explanation: To lessen the chances of a crash occurring, you should make yourself visible, communicate your intentions to others, maintain adequate space cushions, search your path of travel at least 12 seconds ahead, identify and separate hazards, and be prepared to react to changing conditions.

questions.question: When braking on a slippery surface, you should:
questions.answerA: Use both the front and rear brakes.
questions.answerB: Use abrupt pressure on the front brake to prevent locking the front tire.
questions.answerD: Use either brake, but use only one brake.
questions.explanation: When riding on slippery surfaces, you should use both brakes to slow down. Squeeze the brake lever gradually to avoid locking the front wheel and use gentle pressure on the rear brake.

questions.question: Riding directly alongside another vehicle is discouraged because:
questions.answerA: You may have a difficult time getting to a highway exit.
questions.answerB: You may be in the other vehicle’s blind spot.
questions.answerC: You may block the driver's view.
questions.answerD: It prevents other drivers from passing both of you.
questions.explanation: Riding alongside another vehicle is dangerous because you could be riding in the vehicle's blind spot. The driver may enter your lane without warning if they can't see you. The vehicle will also block your route of escape if a hazard arises.

questions.question: Mirror checks:
questions.answerB: Should only be done on long trips.
questions.answerC: Should be part of your normal scanning routine.
questions.answerD: Are not helpful since you can’t do anything about what is behind you.
questions.explanation: Frequent mirror checks should be part of your normal searching routine. Additionally, make a special point of using your mirrors before changing lanes, when stopping at an intersection, and before slowing down.

questions.question: Clothing made of which type of material can offer the best protection to motorcyclists?
questions.answerD: Silk
questions.explanation: Leather garments can provide the greatest level of protection to motorcyclists. It is important to wear clothing that covers your legs and arms entirely when riding a motorcycle.

questions.question: Generally, the body eliminates how many alcoholic drinks per hour?
questions.answerD: Four
questions.explanation: On average, a person's body can eliminate the alcohol content of about one drink per hour. The amount of time required to lower a person's blood alcohol content (BAC) can vary, so it is safest not to operate any motor vehicle after consuming any amount of alcohol.

questions.question: Of the following, the colors that best allow riders to be seen are:
questions.answerD: Black and white.
questions.explanation: To make yourself visible to others, wearing clothing that is bright orange, red, yellow, or green is best.

questions.question: You should do a pre-ride inspection:
questions.answerD: Once a season.
questions.explanation: A small technical fault can have much more serious consequences on a motorcycle than on a car. To avoid these consequences, inspect your motorcycle before every ride.
